conclusion: To determine the pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K, we need to analyze the p-T graph provided.
At T = 200 K, the pressure p is 0.5 x 10^5 Pa. At T = 400 K, the pressure p is 1.0 x 10^5 Pa.
The graph shows a linear relationship between pressure and temperature.
Calculate the slope (m) of the line: m = (1.0 x 10^5 - 0.5 x 10^5) / (400 - 200) = 2.5 x 10^2 Pa/K.
Use the point-slope form of the line equation: p - p1 = m(T - T1).
Substitute T = 600 K into the equation: p - 0.5 x 10^5 = 2.5 x 10^2 (600 - 200).
The pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K is 1.5 x 10^5 Pa.
